question.title: Why does Python get a red carpet to vSphere while Java gets a CAPTCHA and a shrug?
question.body:
VMware’s pyVmomi is the velvet-rope VIP pass to vSphere: whisper pip install pyvmomi, and the data center parts like the Red Sea. It’s a universal remote with actual buttons, not stickers.

Java, meanwhile, gets an escape room. There is a library—somewhere—guarded by a portal that demands an account, three riddles, two CAPTCHAs, a blood oath to the EULA, and an OTP delivered via carrier pigeon. The REST coverage? Like IKEA furniture missing the bag of screws: “Technically a table if you believe hard enough.”

Documentation? Python devs are reading it before their espresso cools. Java devs are spelunking through a SharePoint from the Bronze Age—after clicking “I Agree” 19 times and proving they can identify all squares containing a forklift.

Why make it painful for Java?

  • Security through obscurity (mostly obscurity).

  • KPI-driven gatekeeping (“Look, weekly active logins doubled!”).

  • Untouchable Legacy Portal™ with a sacred cron job from 2009.

  • “Roadmap considerations,” i.e., shrug emoji in business casual.

So if Python gets a red carpet, could Java at least have a hazmat mat? Better yet, go feral: ship a Java SDK that actually mirrors pyVmomi, put the docs in the daylight like it’s the current century, and let us get stuff done. We’ll even read them. After mvn clean install, we’ve got days.

Why does Python get a red carpet to vSphere while Java gets a CAPTCHA and a shrug?

answers.body: I mean there is the "open ended questions" thing now, but this isn't a question at all, it's a rant with a question mark at the end. If you have an issue with the way VMWare makes its APIs available to you, contact their support. Also, while moderately amusing, please tone down the flowery prose by at least 2 notches.

What kind of "advice" do you expect in response to this question?

What did you intend to achieve by asking?

Seriously, the only people who can answer this objectively are VMWare management, and I doubt that they would do that.

The obvious (speculative) explanation is that Python is more popular than Java and VMware's market research may have told them that investing in Python support would be more profitable.

Somehow I doubt that there is a grand conspiracy against Java developers to deliberately make life harder for them.
